Award.AwardTitle: Recruiting and Preparing UHD Mathematics Majors for Houston-Area Classrooms: The UHD Noyce Mathematics Teacher Scholarship Program

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: Over the course of its five years, this Phase I project is providing 30 scholarships to junior and senior mathematics majors preparing to become grades 6-12 mathematics teachers. This proposal is a joint venture among a variety of interested parties, including the Department of Computer and Mathematical Sciences (CMS) at UHD, the Department of Urban Education (UE) at UHD, Aldine Independent School District, Alief Independent School District, and the Houston Community College Central Campus. Given the nature of the student population at the university and the population in the geographic area the university serves, the project is making strong efforts to recruit minority students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In 2011, University of Houston-Downtown was awarded a NSF/Noyce Teacher Scholarship Standard Grant to provide scholarships to mathematics majors seeking secondary mathematics teacher certification. The grant was originally scheduled to end in July 2016 but was able to secure no-cost extensions through July 2020. The major components of the project included: $6000/semester scholarships for students for a maximum of four semesters; summer stipends for early STEM majors to recruit early UHD students to teaching; ongoing community building for mentor/student teachers involved in the project; induction year support; and cross-disciplinary collaboration among UHD faculty. The intellectual merrit is in the design and implementation of a program for recruiting and supporting preservice secondary mathematics teachers who will teach in urban schools in the Houston-area. The number of and diversity of teaching scholars contributes to the broader impact of the project as well as the long-term success of scholars in their teaching careers. 

Our project goals, as described in the initial proposal include:

1. To graduate 30 Noyce Mathematics Teacher Scholarship recipients over the course of five years--This is three cohorts over the course of five years with 10 teachers each. 

Our original goal was to offer 30 scholarships over a five-year period. We had a total of 33 participants. Of those 33 participants, 25 participants are currently teaching mathematics at a secondary level in a high-needs district and 9 are either in their fifth year of teaching or have surpassed the 5 year teaching mark. Compared to the state average of a 30% teacher turnover rate, we have only had 3 participants out of 33 to leave the field.

2. To foster collaboration between Mathematics and Education faculty to develop and co-teach courses in content and pedagogy housed in CMS, specifically, MATH 3303 (Geometry for Teachers) and MATH 3313 (Mathematics Topics for Secondary Teachers). 

The participation of the interdisciplinary faculty in this project has strengthened the bond between the mathematics faculty and the education faculty for the betterment of the secondary mathematics teaching program at UHD. Through collaborative work including developing and teaching content courses for the secondary mathematics certification program; co-presenting and co-publishing in dissemination efforts and programmatic development our leadership team has formed an active mathematics education group with faculty from both departments. 

3. To establish a UHD Noyce Mathematics Teacher community to which each of the scholarship recipients belongs and can remain a part of during their induction year. 

Since the inception of our program, we have been committed to developing a Noyce community within our department. Our goal from the beginning was to offer opportunities in professional development and community engagement for our scholars while enrolled in the certification program at UHD and then once they graduated with an emphasis on providing support for them during their induction teaching years. We have created this community through mechanisms including project meetings with the current and past scholars each semester; classroom visits by the faculty leader team; continued support via email and text and other informal social interactions. The community aspect of this project will be sustained beyond the end of the project via funds from the mathematics department. 

4. To provide early field experiences for undergraduate freshman and sophomore students through the Houston PREP program in hopes of recruiting them for the Noyce scholarships in the future. 

Early field experience efforts had mixed results. While we were not able to recruit many Noyce scholars through this effort, we did see a trend whereby many of those undergraduates participating in the early field experience did eventually pursue a career in teaching via alternative certification. 

5. To provide Noyce scholarship students with exemplary examples of secondary mathematics teaching through hand-picked mentor teachers for field experiences. 

Mentor teachers were handpicked by the leadership faculty of the project. Mentors were chosen from previous inservice teacher PD projects. Eventually, mentor teachers were chosen from graduated Noyce scholars who were in years 3 or 4 of their induction year experience. We received positive feedback from both the mentors and the mentees.
